title.value: Explainable artificial intelligence models for predicting risk of suicide using health administrative data in Quebec
title.justification: This is the complete title of the paper as provided in the first few lines of the document.
title.quote: Explainable artificial intelligence models for predicting risk of suicide using health administrative data in Quebec

extractions.description: The paper focuses on developing sex-specific machine learning models to predict suicide risk using health administrative data from Quebec. It highlights the importance of interpretable AI in helping policymakers make data-driven decisions for improving mental health services and suicide prevention efforts. The study employs models like Logistic Regression, Random Forest, Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), and Multilayer perceptron with SHAP as an interpretability method.

type.justification: The paper involves practical experiments with ML models using real-world data from Quebec to predict suicide risk.
type.quote: This research aimed to develop sex-specific ML models for predicting the population risk of suicide and to interpret the models.

name.justification: The paper extensively discusses developing AI models with interpretability for predicting suicide risks, utilizing SHAP for explanations.
name.quote: Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) proposes shifting toward more transparent AI to address this issue.

name.justification: The paper focuses on developing predictive models using machine learning techniques.
name.quote: Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) have emerged to harness large-scale datasets to enhance risk detection.

name.justification: The application domain of the study is in mental health, specifically focusing on predicting suicide risk.
name.quote: This research aimed to develop sex-specific ML models for predicting the population risk of suicide.

name.justification: The paper explicitly mentions the use of Logistic Regression as one of the predictive models.
name.quote: We trained supervised ML classifications with Logistic Regression (LR)...

is_contributed.justification: Logistic Regression is a commonly used statistical model and not a novel contribution from this paper.
is_contributed.quote: LR assumes a linear relationship between the logit of the outcome and predictor variables.

is_executed.justification: The paper does not mention specific execution details related to CPU or GPU for Logistic Regression.
is_executed.quote: We trained supervised ML classifications with Logistic Regression (LR), Random Forest ...

is_compared.justification: The model's performance is compared against other models like Random Forest, Extreme Gradient Boosting, and MLP.
is_compared.quote: The men’s model showed that the accuracy rate was the highest for XGBoost (0.97), followed by RF (0.96), MLP (0.96) and LR (0.95).

is_compared.justification: Random Forest is compared with other models like Logistic Regression, XGBoost, and MLP in terms of performance.
is_compared.quote: Overall, LR appeared to provide more accurate classification results than the other algorithms when predicting suicide in men.
